description_good_justification: Website succinctly describes the purpose of the project.

version_unique_justification: Released versions can be identified by release tag in GitHub and PyPI.
version_tags_justification: Released versions can be identified by release tag in GitHub and PyPI.
release_notes_justification: Brief release notes are included in Git tags of each release, https://github.com/uber/horovod/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no known vulnerabilities in Horovod itself, but underlying infrastructure - ssh, MPI, NCCL, may have vulnerabilities.  MPI environments are optimized for speed instead of inner-loop security, and are typically secured by VM & network isolation.
report_responses_justification: Majority of the bug reports were acknowledged and provided with the fixes
enhancement_responses_justification: Majority of proposed enhancements were implemented or at least discussed
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: No vulnerabilities have been reported to date
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities have been reported to date
build_justification: Horovod can be build using Python setuptools
build_common_tools_justification: Horovod can be build using Python setuptools
build_floss_tools_justification: Horovod can be build using Python setuptools
test_policy_justification: There is a policy to add tests for any new functionality defined in CONTRIBUTING.md
tests_are_added_justification: The fact that tests were added is visible in Pull Requests
tests_documented_added_justification: There is a policy to add tests for any new functionality defined in CONTRIBUTING.md
know_secure_design_justification: MPI environments are optimized for speed instead of inner-loop security, and are typically secured by VM & network isolation.  As such, security is N/A at Horovod level and needs to be handled by layers below.
crypto_published_justification:
MPI environments are optimized for speed instead of inner-loop security, and are typically secured by VM & network isolation.  As such, security is N/A at Horovod level and needs to be handled by layers below.

We use HMAC SHA-256 digests for network communication between Horovod Driver and Horovod Tasks in Spark, however, this does not fix MPI's internal security weakness.
delivery_mitm_justification: Distributed from PyPI using HTTPS: https://pypi.org/project/horovod/
static_analysis_justification: Manual at this point.  Plan to migrate to automated in new few months.  Primarily complicated due to many false positives.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Python code is being manually checked using Pylint.  C++ code is being manually checked using Clang-Tidy.
static_analysis_often_justification: We're planning to add automatic static code analysis in early 2019
dynamic_analysis_justification: We're planning to add automatic dynamic code analysis in early 2019
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We're planning to add automatic dynamic code analysis in early 2019
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Both assertions and runtime checks are included in the code
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Horovod tests run in Travis CI nightly and on every PR commit - https://travis-ci.org/uber/horovod
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Hyperledger Caliper
description: Caliper is a blockchain benchmark framework which allows users to measure the performance of a specific blockchain implementation with a set of predefined use cases. Caliper will produce reports containing a number of performance indicators, such as TPS (Transactions Per Second), transaction latency, resource utilisation etc. The intent is for Caliper results to be used as a reference in supporting the choice of a blockchain implementation suitable for the user-specific use-cases. The Caliper project references the definitions, metrics, and terminology as defined by the Performance & Scalability Working Group (PSWG).

name: snallygaster
description: snallygaster is a tool that looks for files accessible on web servers that shouldn't be public and can pose a security risk. Typical examples include publicly accessible git repositories, backup files potentially containing passwords or database dumps. In addition it contains a few checks for other security vulnerabilities.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/hannob/snallygaster/blob/master/CONTRIBUTIONS.md
license_location_justification: https://github.com/hannob/snallygaster/blob/master/LICENSE
floss_license_osi_justification:
It is licensed as CC0, which allows to do everything with the code, but for some complicated reasons OSI doesn't accept CC0 as an approved license.
However it is a license the FSFE approves and considers as GPL-compatible:
https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.en.html#CC0
This indirectly makes it "practically OSI-approved", as you can relicense.
documentation_basics_justification: It's a TODO item, but --help gives basic documentation.
documentation_interface_justification: It's a TODO item, but --help gives basic documentation.
repo_public_justification: https://github.com/hannob/snallygaster.git
repo_track_justification: https://github.com/hannob/snallygaster/commits/master
version_semver_justification: Given the lack of an API it is not entirely clear whether this actually is an issue.
build_justification: Python is a scripting language, thus no build system.
warnings_fixed_justification: Project exposes no known python warnings (except for dependencies, where we report them).
crypto_published_justification: There's no cryptographic functionality (except fetching URLs via HTTPS).
static_analysis_justification: pycodestyle, pyflakes, pylint and dlint, all run via CI.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Unclear how this can be met with Python.
discussion_justification: Github Issue tracker and Pull Requests.
english_justification: The project is entirely managed in English.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

FOSSology uses bcrypt as password hashing mechanism provided by PHP
https://github.com/fossology/fossology/blob/5573665ca246009453e947b8fd3efd0e40e4b34c/src/www/ui/core-auth.php#L314-L326
crypto_random_justification:
FOSSology uses bcrypt as password hashing mechanism provided by PHP
https://github.com/fossology/fossology/blob/5573665ca246009453e947b8fd3efd0e40e4b34c/src/www/ui/core-auth.php#L314-L326
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
FOSSology uses bcrypt as password hashing mechanism provided by PHP
https://github.com/fossology/fossology/blob/5573665ca246009453e947b8fd3efd0e40e4b34c/src/www/ui/core-auth.php#L314-L326
discussion_justification:
GitHub and FOSSology mailing lists:
- https://lists.fossology.org/g/fossology/topics
